body:
# The Project
This project is funded by the National Science Foundation's Partnerships for International Research and Education (PIRE) program. The University of Washington group is one of several institutions working on the International Collaboration and Education in Ice Core Science (ICEICS), grant. The goal of the ICEICS project is to use ice-core science to produce a continuous record of the earth's climate for the past 800,000 years. For more information on this project, please visit the ICEICS homepage.

The University of Washington ICEICS group will develop state-of-the-art models to reconstruct the physics of the snow-ice transition and gas transport properties in firn. These community models will be open source and freely downloadable. This modeling work has two components: the gas transport, and firn densification.

Currently, the firn-densification model is ready to run upon downloading. The models are modular, which allows the user to choose which physics to include in the model run and which outputs to produce. Users can also alter the source code as needed. The transient models allow physic properties to evolve over time, which results in more accurate delta-age approximations at times of rapid climate change in the past. This model is currently being hosted on GitHub. 

The models are written in the Python programming language. Python offers an open-source access, ease of development, and scientific computing capabilities.
